title: Autistic Brooklyn Woman Is Drowned at Home

title: Priest Charged With Gun Possession and Harassment

body: Virtually every morning these days, over coffee and newspaper clippings, veteran political organizers, elected officials and labor leaders gather in the offices of the Central Labor Council in Manhattan to plot strategy to defeat a proposal for eliminating party primaries in New York City. title: TUNNEL VISION; Millions Ride the Subway. Only a Few Dare to Hide It.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Brownstones by the Tree-Lined Block

body: Infant mortality in New York City dropped to a record low last year, but remained high in some poor neighborhoods, the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mixed News On Infant Mortality

body: IT'S just 12 feet wide and three stories high, with a little slice of green in the back. This is not the grandest house in Bed-Stuy, but it has certain charms: a fireplace dressed in white Federal-style finery in every room but the kitchen, that slice of lawn and an absolutely rock-solid roof. The furnace is also pretty good. Clear-eyed, with their
title: Habitats/Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; It's the Little Red House That Could Fit the Budget

body: Ah, the Memories Of a Political Life From Liberal Party stalwart to deputy mayor in a Republican City Hall to Democratic mayoral hopeful. Not the typical political route in New York, but Fran Reiter traveled it, and in a single decade. Ms. Reiter was the New York State chairwoman of the Liberal Party when, in 1993, she served as deputy campaign
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: A campaign volunteer for a City Council candidate was charged yesterday with threatening to shoot the incumbent and two aides because he thought they were engaged in dirty campaign tricks, investigators said. The arrest comes just days after another councilman was gunned down at City Hall. In two phone calls to the office of Councilman Hiram
title: Volunteer Accused of Making Threat to Councilman

body: It is often when the prizes are small that the battles seem the most ferocious. Local elections for offices like City Council can attract neighborhood gadflies and the occasional oddball. But they are also frequently bruising street fights, full of threats and intrigue, promises and favors. It was in a corner of that often-overlooked political
title: SHOOTING AT CITY HALL: THE SUSPECT; Combustible Mix Behind City Hall Shooting

body: What's Behind The Mind No matter how sunny the day, there's one place where an electrical storm is always raging. It's at a familiar altitude: behind your eyes. title: FAMILY FARE

body: To many in central Brooklyn, Councilman James E. Davis was the man whose face was the centerpiece of red-and-white campaign posters on scores of bus shelters and store windows in the area. title: SHOOTING AT CITY HALL: THE COUNCILMAN; Davis Recalled as Maverick Who Rallied Against Violence

body: If there is one thing that everyone in Brooklyn who knew Othniel Boaz Askew could agree on, it is that he had big plans. At 31, he had tried his hand at the real estate business, rebuilding a row house in Fort Greene, and had served in the military, friends said. But he was always looking for the next big thing. ''He had grandiose ideas about
title: SHOOTING AT CITY HALL: THE GUNMAN; A Newcomer With Big Plans And Mysterious Complaints

body: A studio grows in Brooklyn. O.K., it doesn't exactly look like one. At the moment, Sound Stage 1 of the new Steiner Studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is hard-hat country. title: On Brooklyn Back Lot, Finally, Some Action; After Years of Talk, a Movie Studio Is Being Built at the Navy Yard

title: Real Estate Firms Agree to Share Listings of Brooklyn Properties

body: Since its inception 30 years ago, New York City's housing court has sometimes resembled a chaotic netherworld worthy of Dickens. title: Boom Times in the City's Housing Courts

body: THE LAST GOOD SEASON Brooklyn, the Dodgers, and Their Final Pennant Race Together. By Michael Shapiro. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95. ON Friday, April 18, 1958, the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants, 6-5, and grown men wept in Brooklyn. Some are weeping yet. The Dodgers left Ebbets Field nearly 46 years ago,
title: Hitler, Stalin, O'Malley and Moses

body: A driver rammed a white van into the front doors of four firehouses in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, injuring no one but damaging one of the doors so badly that the fire company inside was unable to respond to two calls, fire officials said. Although the same van appears to have struck all four firehouses, fire officials said, the driver has
title: Van Rams Firehouses At 4 Sites in Brooklyn

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Cabaret, the Champagne of New York

title: ARTS BRIEFING

body: The streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant were calm yesterday, a day after a fatal police shooting spurred the friends of the man killed to threaten police officers at close range and kick their patrol cars. The man, Carlos Lopez, 19, was the second to be killed by the police in two days. And late Thursday night, the police shot a third person in Brooklyn
title: Brooklyn Woman Is Injured in 3rd Police Shooting

title: Police Kill Man They Say Had Just Killed Another

title: Man With Gun Is Shot and Killed by the Police

body: DAVID ARMSTRONG collects tiny cartes de visites portraits, late-19th-century photographs printed on stiff, palm-sized cards that were presented as keepsakes to loved ones. title: AT HOME WITH: David Armstrong; Softening the Line Between Past and Present

body: A week after being removed from a committee as punishment for voting against an increase in the property tax, City Councilman James E. title: Councilman Who Lost Post Threatens To File Suit

body: February, which is Black History Month, is a good time to explore the exotic foods at these often overlooked African restaurants. title: GOOD EATING; Out of Africa

body: Debbie Does Pratt Q. An advertisement for the Off Broadway play ''Debbie Does Dallas'' reminded me that I was once told that parts of the original movie were filmed in New York. Is that true? title: F.Y.I.

body: Until a hand-held anemometer -- a wind gauge -- becomes widely available to New Yorkers, pinpointing the coldest and windiest point in the city will be impossible. But there is a contender in Brooklyn: when pedestrians approach 1 Hanson Place, home to the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, they wrap their coats more tightly, secure their hats, and hunch
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Outside This Famed Bank, Everyone Knows It's Windy

body: There will probably be no more Ping-Pong, no more Foosball, no more homework help. The basketballs will stop bouncing, and the computers will cease humming. Last month, the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club informed the parents of the roughly 600 children who attend the club that it would close in June unless the parents were willing to pay its
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; A Struggling Children's Club Makes Parents a Costly Offer

author: Ross B. Intelisano is a lawyer.
body: Beginning today, New Yorkers must dial 1, plus the area code, plus the seven-digit telephone number, to complete any local telephone call made within or between New York City boroughs. That's 11 digits in total, whether the call is from Manhattan to Manhattan or Brooklyn to Queens. The Federal Communications Commission says this change will
title: Ending the 212 Clique

body: A private prison company at the center of state inquiries into influence peddling in Albany has a checkered history in metropolitan New York, having been the subject of two federal investigations. Prosecutors in Manhattan and the lobbying commission in Albany are looking into whether the company, Correctional Services Corporation, violated any laws
title: Prison Company Under Scrutiny Once Again

body: A very winning pair of losers have moved into the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where they are bringing new refinement to the popular art of disgruntlement. title: THEATER REVIEW; An Acting Lesson, With a Grovel and a Strut, in Two Plays

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A See-Through Library of Shifting Shapes and Colors

body: Instead of having a childhood, Kelly Brown, 23, grew up with responsibility, worry and fear. ''I was the oldest,'' she said, ''so the majority of the time when I was growing up, I had to look after the family.'' Ms. Brown did not have much help in those days. She did not meet her natural father until she was 8, and has rarely seen him since then,
title: The Neediest Cases; A Girl's Childhood Is Lost to the Responsibilities of Surrogate Motherhood

body: The forest of white plaster icicles still hangs over the bar. Strings of miniature Christmas lights still cascade down the wall in back. But something happened last month at Frank's Cocktail Lounge in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, that struck the fear of gentrification into Micaela Birmingham's heart. Walking past the corner of Fulton Avenue and Lafayette
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; A Sign Might Be More Than a Sign, But Frank's Lounge Stays the Same

body: It has not been so very long since New York was a city where, it was said, if you were killed on the street, people would just step over you and keep walking and where the police were more likely to be seen seen as intruders rather than protectors. In some neighborhoods there is less psychological distance from those times than others. Still, it
title: Little Real Outrage Over a Thinner Blue Line

title: POSTINGS: Downtown Brooklyn Project; Reborn Building to Aid the Arts
